00008 
00009 /*
00010  * Script definitions
00011  */
00012 
00013 class Script
00014 {
00015 public:
00016     struct SCHDstruct
00017     {
00018         /* Script name.
00019 
00020          NOTE: You should handle the name "Main" (case insensitive) with
00021          care. With tribunal, modders got the ability to add 'start
00022          scripts' to their mods, which is a script that is run at
00023          startup and which runs throughout the game (I think.)
00024 
00025          However, before Tribunal, there was only one startup script,
00026          called "Main". If mods wanted to make their own start scripts,
00027          they had to overwrite Main. This is obviously problem if
00028          multiple mods to this at the same time.
00029 
00030          Although most mods have switched to using Trib-style startup
00031          scripts, some legacy mods might still overwrite Main, and this
00032          can cause problems if several mods do it. I think the best
00033          course of action is to NEVER overwrite main, but instead add
00034          each with a separate unique name and add them to the start
00035          script list. But there might be other problems with this
00036          approach though.
00037          */
00038 
00039         NAME32 name;
00040 
00041         // These describe the sizes we need to allocate for the script
00042         // data.
00043         int numShorts, numLongs, numFloats, scriptDataSize, stringTableSize;
00044     }; // 52 bytes
00045 
00046     SCHDstruct data;
00047 
00048     std::vector<std::string> varNames; // Variable names
00049     std::vector<char> scriptData; // Compiled bytecode
00050     std::string scriptText; // Uncompiled script
00051 
00052     void load(ESMReader &esm);
00053 };
00054 }
00055 #endif
